subject: RE: [junit] Thanks - running out of memory
msgSnippet: Ooops on my part. I was trying to stimulate conversation to explicitly define best . Next time, I will have to select possible alternative choices more
messageBody:
Ooops on my part.

I was trying to stimulate conversation to explicitly define "best".

Next time, I will have to select possible alternative choices more
carefully.

Needless to say, I would never ask my clients to add 1 GB of RAM to run my
software unless I had exhausted all other possible alternatives.
-----Original Message-----
From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com]On Behalf Of J.
B. Rainsberger
Sent: Saturday, January 21, 2006 9:04 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Thanks - running out of memory


Robert Lucente wrote:
> Thanks for the help.
>
> I am a newbie to Java/JUnit. I am going to begin by examining the
suggestion
> in Friday, January 20, 2006 1:41 PM about setUp/tearDown.
>
> "rarely the best one"
>
> It all depend on how you define "best".
>
> If I am running tests on my PC and don't have a lot of time to delve
into
> the memory problem, why not add that 1 GB of memory to the PC and meet
the
> deliverable date ?

This is precisely the kind of thinking that leads to dissatisfied
customers. Are /they/ going to just pop in 1 GB RAM to run your
software? A memory problem in testing often means a memory problem in
the production code.

> If this is an exercise to learn the technology, then I would investigate
> setUp/tearDown, lazy loading and so on.

I think it's one of our basic responsibilities as programmers to take
reasonable precautions against writing software that arbitrarily sucks
up large amounts of memory. I assume, of course, that we intend our
customers to let our software run for days, weeks, months at a time.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.info
Your guide to software craftsmanship
JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
2005 Gordon Pask Award for contribution Agile Software Practice
